Situation1: A sudden route closure forces dozens of flights into tight holding stacks around the airport.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story:
The radio crackled with urgency as I scanned the radar, my eyes darting between the blips stacking up in tight circles. A major route closure had just been announced, and now dozens of flights were circling, waiting for my instructions. The pressure was immense—every decision I made could mean the difference between order and chaos in the crowded airspace. My headset felt heavier than usual, pressing against my temples as I tried to keep my voice steady for the pilots depending on me.

But in the back of my mind, another responsibility gnawed at me. Today was election day, and I had promised myself I would vote. The polling station was open all day, and my schedule was supposed to be light, but now, with the sudden crisis, I couldn’t see how I’d get away. I felt torn—my duty to keep the skies safe was absolute, but so was my right and responsibility as a citizen. The minutes ticked by, each one tightening the knot in my stomach as I wrestled with the impossible choice between my roles.
